qas.question: What is the primary trigger for immunological changes in teens?
What specific hormone catalyzes these changes in females?
Which specific hormone precipitates the change in immunology in males?
Adolescent immunological changes can also result in what?

answers.text: increased risk in developing pubescent and post-pubescent autoimmunity

qas.question: Evidence suggests that receptors on B cells may do what?

answers.text: detect sex hormones in the system

context: During adolescence, the human body undergoes various physical, physiological and immunological changes triggered and mediated by <a0_0>hormones<a0_0/>, of which the most significant in females is <a1_0>17-β-oestradiol (an oestrogen)<a1_0/> and, in males, is <a2_0>testosterone<a2_0/>. Oestradiol usually begins to act around the age of 10 and testosterone some months later. There is evidence that these steroids act directly not only on the primary and secondary sexual characteristics but also have an effect on the development and regulation of the immune system, including an <a3_0>increased risk in developing pubescent and post-pubescent autoimmunity<a3_0/>. There is also some evidence that cell surface receptors on B cells and macrophages may <a4_0>detect sex hormones in the system<a4_0/>.
